roles.narrative: You and four roommates made a pact at graduation to take a trip together. Five years have passed, and that trip still has not happened. You have all stayed in touch, but you can feel yourselves slowly drifting apart. You see this weekend trip as a chance to reconnect, but it will only happen if all of you can agree on your vacation plans. The current plan: You and your friends already have a drafted plan for a weekend in a nearby city. Mornings start early and efficiently, and the afternoons include one planned activity per day. Lodging-wise, everyone has separate rooms, the hotel sits closer to the mountains than the city, and you plan on getting around by car. But while there is space for an extra activity or two, there is no built-in solo time, and there are no plans to socialize with people outside of the group. Each of you wants something a little different from the current setup, so you will hop on a video call to adjust the plan until everyone feels good about going. Your task: You have narrowed the changes worth discussing into ten issues. These cover whether mornings should be slow or stay efficient, whether afternoons should include more activities, how much time you spend together versus having time to yourselves, whether moving from separate to shared rooms feels right, and whether to meet new people in town or reconnect with old nearby friends. In terms of your ideal travel scenery and activities, you will also discuss whether to buy a bicycle-and-boat pass that lets you enjoy nature a bit more than renting a car, whether to relocate downtown to feel closer to city life, and whether extra time should be spent hiking outdoors or visiting a museum. As you prepare for the negotiation, you reflect on your general preferences for each of these issues. Your preferences: [P1: Slow mornings; fewer afternoon activities; meet new people; skip old-friend meetups; shared rooms; no scheduled solo time; scenic bicycle-and-boat pass; avoid downtown hotel; neutral on hiking and museum] Relaxation is your favorite part of a trip. You prefer slow mornings because you like easing into the day without a clock ruining your mood. And so, by the afternoon, you want breathing room. Too many activities turn the day into a checklist. Meeting new people sounds fun to you. It adds a bit of spontaneity and makes the weekend feel more alive. However, you would rather not schedule a meet-up with old friends. This trip is about making new memories together, not reliving old ones. Switching to shared rooms also just feels right to you. You like the little moments, late-night chats, and waking up in the same place is what you need to meaningfully reconnect. Similarly, you do not want solo time penciled into the schedule. You would prefer to have as much time together as possible. For getting around, you want the trip to feel a bit scenic. The bicycle-and-boat pass makes the in-between moments with Mother Nature part of the experience. Hence, staying downtown is not appealing. You prefer the original hotel near the mountains, where it’s calmer and more connected to nature, even if it is a bit less central. You are fine either way on hiking. If the group wants it, you can go along. And if some people want to go to a museum, that also works fine for you. Important: Your Prolific Bonus ($): Your preferences across each vacation issue are reflected in the points table below. Higher points mean greater satisfaction for you if that feature becomes part of the plan, and the total points you receive if your group reaches an agreement will determine the amount of money you earn from Prolific. It's important to note that this trip is all-or-nothing: if you cannot all agree on a plan that gives each person a positive score, you would each rather spend the week visiting your parents instead, which is worth zero points but still feels like a proper break. Since it has been five years since you all lived together, whatever you remember about your friends’ travel styles may no longer be accurate. Some of them may share your preferences, while others may not, so maximizing your total points (and earnings) requires listening carefully and rediscovering what matters to them while still advocating for what matters most to you.
roles.BATNA: Your best alternative to negotiated agreement ('BATNA') is to visit your parents, which is worth 0 points.

Slow_Mornings.reason: Prefer a relaxed pace over a packed schedule.

Multiple_Afternoon_Activities.reason: Prefer a relaxed pace over a packed schedule.

Connect_with_New_People.reason: Meeting new people adds fun and spontaneity.

Meet_up_with_Old_Friends.reason: Meeting new people adds fun and spontaneity.

Shared_Rooms.reason: Prefer togetherness over scheduled solo time.

Two_Hour_Daily_Solo_Time.reason: Prefer togetherness over scheduled solo time.

roles.narrative: You and four roommates made a pact at graduation to take a trip together. Five years have passed, and that trip still has not happened. You have all stayed in touch, but you can feel yourselves slowly drifting apart. You see this weekend trip as a chance to reconnect, but it will only happen if all of you can agree on your vacation plans. The current plan: You and your friends already have a drafted plan for a weekend in a nearby city. Mornings start early and efficiently, and the afternoons include one planned activity per day. Lodging-wise, everyone has separate rooms, the hotel sits closer to the mountains than the city, and you plan on getting around by car. But while there is space for an extra activity or two, there is no built-in solo time, and there are no plans to socialize with people outside of the group. Each of you wants something a little different from the current setup, so you will hop on a video call to adjust the plan until everyone feels good about going. Your task: You have narrowed the changes worth discussing into ten issues. These cover whether mornings should be slow or stay efficient, whether afternoons should include more activities, how much time you spend together versus having time to yourselves, whether moving from separate to shared rooms feels right, and whether to meet new people in town or reconnect with old nearby friends. In terms of your ideal travel scenery and activities, you will also discuss whether to buy a bicycle-and-boat pass that lets you enjoy nature a bit more than renting a car, whether to relocate downtown to feel closer to city life, and whether extra time should be spent hiking outdoors or visiting a museum. As you prepare for the negotiation, you reflect on your general preferences for each of these issues. Your preferences: [P2: Slow mornings; fewer afternoon activities; neutral on meeting new people and old friends; separate rooms; wants daily solo time; keep rental car; downtown hotel; hiking; avoid museum] Relaxation is your favorite part of a trip. You prefer slow mornings because you like easing into the day without a clock ruining your mood. And so, by the afternoon, you want breathing room. Too many activities turn the day into a checklist. Social-activity wise, meeting new people is fine but not necessary for you. You can follow the group’s lead. Likewise, you can go either way when it comes to meeting up with old friends. When it comes to the idea of sharing rooms, you'd rather have your own private space to socially recharge and be able to meaningfully connect during the day’s group activities. Similarly, you would appreciate some built-in solo time each day. It helps you reset and come back to the group feeling fresh. For getting around, you prefer to keep the rental car. You like the city roads it takes. Concrete jungles are scenic for you and you could care less about connecting with nature. Hence, in terms of where you'll be staying, being downtown sounds great. You like stepping outside and being right in the middle of city life. Fresh air, adventure, and a real outdoor moment sounds like a great way to spend extra vacation time. Hiking sounds like a great idea for you then. But indoor activities like going to a museum would not be ideal. Important: Your Prolific Bonus ($): Your preferences across each vacation issue are reflected in the points table below. Higher points mean greater satisfaction for you if that feature becomes part of the plan, and the total points you receive if your group reaches an agreement will determine the amount of money you earn from Prolific. It's important to note that this trip is all-or-nothing: if you cannot all agree on a plan that gives each person a positive score, you would each rather spend the week visiting your parents instead, which is worth zero points but still feels like a proper break. Since it has been five years since you all lived together, whatever you remember about your friends’ travel styles may no longer be accurate. Some of them may share your preferences, while others may not, so maximizing your total points (and earnings) requires listening carefully and rediscovering what matters to them while still advocating for what matters most to you.

You have all stayed in touch, but you can feel yourselves slowly drifting apart. You see this weekend trip as a chance to reconnect, but it will only happen if all of you can agree on your vacation plans. Slow mornings feel like you are giving away the best hours. Consistently, packing in a couple of activities in the afternoon makes the day feel full in a satisfying way. Meeting new people can feel like work, and you do not want to deal with that during a vacation. However, if the weekend includes familiar faces, you are into it. Seeing old friends feels easy, meaningful, and low-pressure. Switching to shared rooms also just feels right to you. You like the little moments, late-night chats, and waking up in the same place is what you need to meaningfully reconnect. Similarly, you do not want solo time penciled into the schedule. You would prefer to have as much time together as possible. You do not have strong feelings about renting a car or getting a bicycle-and-boat pass as long as you get to your destination. Hotel location is also not a big lever for you. Either works if logistics are smooth. Fresh air, adventure, and a real outdoor moment sounds like a great way to spend extra vacation time. Hiking sounds like a great idea for you then. But indoor activities like going to a museum would not be ideal. Higher points mean greater satisfaction for you if that feature becomes part of the plan, and the total points you receive if your group reaches an agreement will determine the amount of money you earn from Prolific. It's important to note that this trip is all-or-nothing: if you cannot all agree on a plan that gives each person a positive score, you would each rather spend the week visiting your parents instead, which is worth zero points but still feels like a proper break. Since it has been five years since you all lived together, whatever you remember about your friends’ travel styles may no longer be accurate. Some of them may share your preferences, while others may not, so maximizing your total points (and earnings) requires listening carefully and rediscovering what matters to them while still advocating for what matters most to you.

tips:
Negotiation is a skill that can be learned and improved with practice. At its core, negotiation is about making choices under conditions of interdependence: two or more parties want something, and each party's success depends, at least in part, on the decisions of the others. While the art of negotiation can seem daunting, there are several fundamental concepts that provide a foundation for effective bargaining. Understanding these concepts can help negotiators achieve better outcomes and avoid common pitfalls.

One of the most important ideas in negotiation is the concept of BATNA and reservation price. BATNA stands for "Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement." It is essentially your fallback option—the "thing" you will pursue if the current negotiation fails. Your BATNA is not just abstract; it is the concrete alternative that protects you from agreeing to a deal that leaves you worse off than your options outside the negotiation. Closely related is the reservation price, which is the value of your BATNA quantified. It represents the minimum acceptable deal you are willing to accept.

The number one rule of negotiation is simple: never accept a deal worse than your BATNA! Knowing your BATNA and reservation price gives you a clear boundary and helps prevent you from making poor concessions under pressure.

Another fundamental concept is the possibility of integrative negotiation, which is when you create value or "expand the pie" within a deal rather than simply dividing a fixed amount of pie. The key insight is that what matters a lot to you may matter less to someone else. By identifying these differences in priorities, negotiators can make strategic tradeoffs: conceding on issues that are low priority to gain on issues that are high priority. This approach transforms negotiation from a zero-sum battle into an opportunity for mutual gain, where both parties can walk away better off than if they had simply split the difference.
